_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ExxonMobil Beaumont Polyethylene Plant
                                                                  Risk Management Plan
                                                                    Executive Summary

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The ExxonMobil Chemical Company Beaumont Polyethylene Plant (BPEP) utilizes a systematic approach to Operations Integrity Management to prevent on-site human exposure and to minimize the potential for any off site exposure. 

The Operations Integrity Management System (OIMS) is ExxonMobil¿s approach to managing activities related to safety, health, and the environment. The overall structure and scope of OIMS have been established through ExxonMobil Corporation¿s Operations Integrity Management Framework and include the following systems:

- Management Leadership, Commitment, and Accountability
- Risk Assessment and Management
- Facilities Design and Construction
- Information / Documentation
- Personnel and Training including:
     - Personnel Safety
     - Health
     - Personnel 
     - Training
- Operations and Maintenance including:
     - Operations and Maintenance Procedures
     - Work Permits
     - Critical Equipment
     - Mechanical Integrity
     - Environmental Protection
     - Regulatory Compliance
     - Operations Interface Management
- Management of Change
- Third-Party Services
- Incident Reporting, Investigation, and Analysis
- Community Awareness, Emergency Preparedness
- Operations Assessment and Improvement

BPEP has an ongoing accident prevention program and detailed Plant emergency response plan that involves the participation of local fire, rescue and hospital facilities. BPEP is certified as an OSHA STAR Work Site for complying with the most stringent health and safety standards set by OSHA. BPEP has been an OSHA STAR worksite since 1984, successfully completing five subsequent OSHA STAR inspections.

BPEP, in addit

ion to complying with all applicable environmental laws and regulations, is committed to reduce overall emissions and waste generation from operations wherever technically and economically feasible. This is part of ExxonMobil¿s commitment to safeguarding and protecting the physical environment.


DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The ExxonMobil Beaumont Polyethylene Plant is a world-scale producer of low density, linear low density and high density polyethylene resins manufactured on three (3) BASF® high pressure tubular reactors and three (3) Unipol® low pressure reactors.

The Plant site occupies 300 acres near the Beaumont Municipal Airport. It has 240 acres of developed area for office, manufacturing and warehouse storage. 

The manufacturing processes at BPEP utilize EPA RMP regulated substances including Butene, Ethylene, Hydrogen, isoPentane, Propylene and Vinyl Acetate.


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

BPEP has developed programs to comply with the industry's most stringent environmental, health and safety standards including the Chemical Manufacturers Association's Responsible Care program and OSHA's PSM standard. 

Additionally, BPEP is certified as an OSHA STAR Work Site for complying with the most stringent health and safety standards set by OSHA. BPEP has been an OSHA STAR worksite since 1984.  Facilities in the STAR program are required to demonstrate exemplary safety performance and agree to work cooperatively with OSHA to serve as an example for other industry to follow.  OSHA STAR participants are audited by OSHA for compliance every few years.  BPEP has earned the prestigious STAR recognition and has maintained it through five OSHA inspections over a twenty-year period.

BPEP takes a systematic, proactive approach to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our process safety management systems address each of the essential features of successful acciden

t prevention programs including:

-Process safety information           -Pre-startup review
-Process hazard analysis              -Compliance audits
-Operating procedures		             -Incident investigation
-Training                                      -Employee participation
-Mechanical Integrity                    -Hot work permit
-Management of change                -Contractor safety

In addition to our industry leading management programs, we have designed state of the art systems and equipment to control, prevent, detect and mitigate potential accidental releases.

BPEP employs extensive mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance programs to ensure the integrity of our equipment and safety systems.  Our mechanical integrity program uses equipment surveillance and preventive maintenance activities to identify equipment that may be deteriorating and in need of repair or replacement, before failure occurs.  This program also specifies the repairs (or parts replacement) needed to return equipment to acceptable specifications.

BPEP's employees are trained to safely perform their assigned tasks.  Our training program includes initial training as well as periodic refresher training and training updates when major process or equipment changes are made.  As part of our training, we include provisions for ensuring that employees understand the training, including written tests and field demonstrations.

The processes at BPEP have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The Accident Prevention Program summarized previously is applied to all covered processes at the plant.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors.

In addition to the Accident Prevention Program activities, BPEP utilizes safety features in and around the process operating units to aid in, (1) quickly detecting a release, (2) containing/controlling a relea

se, and (3) reducing the consequences of (mitigating) a release.  The following types of safety features are utilized in various processes:

Release Detection

     - Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
     - TV surveillance cameras

Release Containment/Control

     - Process pressure relief valves that discharge to a flare system for capturing and incinerating episodic releases
     - Valving to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated)
     - Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)
     - Curbing and/or diking to contain liquid releases
     - Redundant equipment and instrumentation 
     - Atmospheric pressure relief devices

Release Mitigation

     - Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
     - Deluge system for specific equipment
     - Trained emergency response personnel
     - Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
     - Blast resistant buildings to protect critical control systems and personnel


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Since June 1999, BPEP experienced two accidental releases of ethylene that resulted in damage to plant equipment and one accidental release of propylene that resulted in an employee requiring minor medical treatment.  No public receptor was affected as a result of these releases.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

BPEP's emergency response program serves as a line of defense against accidental releases and other emergencies and provides the procedures for reacting to accidental releases and other emergencies if they occur. BPEP maintains a written emergency response plan at the facility and is included in the community response plan. 

BPEP is a member of the Sabine Neches Chiefs Association (SNCA) and the Jefferson County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). These organizations consist of industrial and municipal fire departments, Red Cross, Civil Defense and law enforcement agencies in Jefferson and Orange

Counties and are available to provide assistance in the event of major emergency. 

BPEP is a participant in the Southeast Texas Alerting Network (STAN).  STAN is a public awareness telephone information system designed to communicate important information about emergencies, high profile events, and general industrial activity to the people of Southeast Texas. STAN represents a partnership between our area's media, industry, and local emergency management to enhance public communication and emergency response in Hardin, Jefferson, and Orange Counties. Informational messages placed on the STAN line are voluntary and done in addition to any requirement to activate the Emergency Alert System (EAS). Emergency messages that require the public to take action are coordinated with local emergency management officials.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

     - Continued implementation of ¿Safety Excellence Process and ¿Nobody Gets Hurt
     - Continued emphasis on Hazard Recognition skills
     - Drive improvement to be Best in Class in reducing High Pressure process emissions.
     - Provide additional closed-circuit television (CCTV) monitoring capabilities in the process areas.
     - Continued Piping and Instrumentation diagram and Safety Relief Review updates.
     - The key element of our risk management plan is to drive continuous improvement in our Operating Integrity Management Systems.
